Title: Series: Twelve Sibyls and Personifications of Synagogue and Ecclesia
Description: Prudencia (Prudence); a female personification of prudence seen in half-length, with calipers in her left hand and a mirror in her right; in an arched frame and with decorative elements surrounding it. c.1530 Woodcut
Producer name: Print made by: Lucas van Leyden
Curator's comments: This print has been cut out from a larger sheet, in which it was flanked by a scene of the Flight into Egypt to the l and a scene of the Madonna and Child to the r in the top register, and a framed personification of envy, with representations of the sibyls Europaea and Cimmeria in bottom register. This larger sheet was one of fourteen blocks that were published together by Doen Pietersz. in Amsterdam around 1530. According to New Hollstein, the majority of the Old Testament scenes are by Jacob Cornelisz. van Oostsanen and the personifications of vices and virtues with ornamental frames are stylisitcally similar and may also be attributable to the same artist.
Bibliographic references: New Hollstein (Dutch & Flemish) / The New Hollstein: Dutch and Flemish etchings, engravings and woodcuts 1450-1700 (p.244, sheet D (above)) (Lucas van Leyden - book illustration related to Lucas van Leyden and his workshop)
